headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: "Moms For Liberty" Wants DeSantis' Book Bans In More States; Court Docs: Man Who Drove Off Cliff With Family In Car Says He Was Pulling Over To Check Tires, Wife Disagrees; "Surviving Uvalde: Inside A School Shooting" Airs Sunday At 8PM ET/PT. Aired 2:30-3p ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Might I suggest instead of anal sex, perhaps we could go back to teaching cursive.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This book is not appropriate, and it is in your schools.ELLE REEVE, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Moms for Liberty is a parent activist group. It began in Florida in 2021 to protest public schools being closed for COVID and mask mandates. The group became a frequent and spicy presence at school board meetings.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This is about more than masks for the record.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: But now there are more than 250 Moms for Liberty chapters nationwide, the group says. And it has gained major conservative allies and morphed into something else, a campaign against supposed indoctrination of children on race and sexuality.

utterances.speaker: DARCY SCHOENING, CHAPTER CHAIR, MOMS FOR LIBERTY, EL PASO COUNTY, COLORADO
utterances.sentences: I have the right to say, I don't want my kids to learn this. I don't agree with this movement, and that's my right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: So books should fall into that category as well.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: We wanted to understand what's driving these moms on a deeper level than some viral videos. So we met with the Moms for Liberty chapter in El Paso County, Colorado.For conservatives, they won majorities on these three school boards in 2021. Leader Darcy Schoening let us watch a meeting where they talked about how to pressure those boards into making the policies they want.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: What school districts are most of you guys in? REEVESome of those books listed do talk about sex. But according to the Supreme Court's definition of obscenity, they're not porn. (on-camera): I've read a lot of criticism of your group. People say that this is kind of like a moral panic, that people have an irrational fear of what's going on.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: We're not looking to ban books. We're not looking to burn books. We just need to get back to a system where parents know what their kids are learning, and for the most part, it's educational and not political.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: One of the books on your list is Kurt Vonnegut's "Slaughterhouse-Five." I mean, it's considered one of the classics of modern literature.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: Right. I read that in high school. Yes.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Well, why would -- would you want that removed from the library?

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: No, we don't -- again, age appropriate.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: It's on list.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: What might not be appropriate for a six-year-old is appropriate for a 15-year-old.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Is someone assigning of first grader at the "Slaughterhouse- Five"?

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: No. But again, it's the right of the parents to know that it's there, that their children have access to something that they may not have access to at home.REEVE (voice-over): One of the big issues right now is pronouns. In March, Colorado's District 11 School Board considered a proposal to prevent teachers from asking kids their pronouns, sparking protests.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Teachers can no longer ask kids. They're pronouns. That's right. No more grooming kids with pronouns in D11.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: The school board has tabled the proposal.(on-camera): Why is asking a child their pronouns indoctrination.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: If you ask my children who are seven and eight, what are your pronouns? They don't even know what that is.So when you ask that, you're planting the seed in their minds that they maybe should identify as another gender or that identifying as another gender is hip or cool. Hey, my teacher's asking me, so maybe this is what I should do.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: But I certainly never felt that way about my teachers. Like I didn't learn I was heterosexual from my health teacher. It was from like, watching '90s movies with Brad Pitt in it.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. Well, and -- but -- and I think that's how most of us are.REEVE (voice-over): We wanted to hear what some of the more liberal parents had to say. Some of them set in on the meeting and one passed me this note, calling it a hate group. The next day we met with those parents. (on-camera): For the record, have any of your kids ever come home and said, I am feeling peer pressured to be gay or trans?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: No.REEVE (voice-over): Naomi Lopez is a speech pathologist and works in a District 11 school.

utterances.speaker: NAOMI LOPEZ, SPEECH PATHOLOGIST
utterances.sentences: First of all, we're not going around saying, OK, you know, I want you to think about it. What gender are you?REEVE (on-camera): Yes.

utterances.speaker: LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: Like that's not happening, period.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: They say it's happening.

utterances.speaker: LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: It's not. My personal beliefs, my personal viewpoint on the world does not come into the classroom. We are professionals with degrees in pedagogy.REEVE (voice-over): And she's also the mom of a transgender student.

utterances.speaker: LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: So -- I'm sorry, can you ask me again because I'm getting pissed off.REEVE (on-camera): What -- you want to talk about that first? Why does it make you emotional to talk about this stuff?

utterances.speaker: LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: So I get emotional when other people who don't have children who are transgender or queer place an assumption on it for the sake of persecution, based on their own belief.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: When you're putting all this curriculum everywhere and you're telling kids, hey, come -- you could come talk to me behind your parents' back, I got your back.I mean, there's a clear move to bring more of that into our schools, and it's just not the school's place.

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Well, who is directing that?

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: Teachers unions and our president and a lot of funding sources. And teachers' unions are also heavily backing the curriculum that we're bringing into schools.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Why would they want more kids to be gay and trans?

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: Because it breaks down the family unit, which breaks down traditional conservative values. It breaks down a lot of things in this country. It changes the way that people think. It changes the way that people handle politics.REEVE (voice-over): Of course, there's no evidence of a coordinated plot to make kids trans. (on-camera): When I hear those thoughts about like some sort of concerted effort to make people gay, does it sound like a conspiracy theory to you?

utterances.speaker: SCHOENING
utterances.sentences: It's not a conspiracy theory that the state, whether you're talking about Colorado or the federal government, is taking a stronger and stronger hand in public education in raising our kids.So do I think that for some reason people want everyone to be gay? That's a mischaracterization of what I think. I think that people will use -- you know, the people that want to erode away at parental rights, the left, the teachers' unions, they'll use LGBTQ or whatever may be the case at the time. Those are just tools to erode away at parental rights. REEVE (voice-over): The last D11 meeting of the school year was mostly about student awards and performances. The board seemed to anticipate the few Moms for Liberty members in the crowd.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: As we reflect over the last year, removing rogue woke clubs, teachers, woke teachers and woke counselors from D11 is a must.

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: And a couple of students push back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If you remove teacher's ability to ask for pronouns, you'll remove the ability for safe spaces to exist, taking away the safety of your students.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I want to recognize our students and the support staff that are supporting our students out there. LOPEZ

utterances.speaker: REEVE
utterances.sentences: Elle Reeve, CNN, Colorado Springs, Colorado.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Now to some of the other headlines we're watching this hour.Beloved musical icon, Jimmy Buffett, is in the hospital for an undisclosed medical reason. He was set to perform this week in Charleston, South Carolina, was forced to cancel his show. In a message to fans, he described his ailment in a way only Jimmy Buffett by saying, "Growing old is not for sissies, I promise you." A dramatic rescue. A Douglas County, Nebraska, Sheriff's Office in Omaha is looking for these brave individuals. They rushed in to help deputies lift off a car off a motorcyclist who got trapped after a crash. They were able to get the car up off the ground just enough to pull the person out. That's amazing. Finally, a break-in at the Vatican. This video was shot late last night. It's a car driving through St. Peter's Square after ramming through one of the outer gates at Vatican City. The Vatican says the driver was taken into custody and is now receiving psychiatric treatment.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: A California man accused of driving his wife and two young kids off a cliff on purpose told police he pulled off the road to check the tire pressure. Those details from court records obtained by the "San Francisco Chronical."His wife told first responders he took the Tesla nearly 300 feet over the cliff on purpose. "The Chronical" cited a search warrant affidavit for the details. Fortunately, everyone survived the impact. Dharmesh Patel was charged in January with three counts of attempted murder. Let's bring in CNN's Camile Bernal, joining us with the latest. Camila, bring us up to speed with what you're learning about this case.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: We know you'll watch the next court appearance. Incredible they all survived, just looking at the unreal images of that crash.Camila Bernal, thank you for that. Brianna?

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: It has been nearly a year since one of the deadliest school shootings in American history. A gunman killing 19 students and two teachers at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas.And it took law enforcement 77 minutes to confront the killer as children inside dialed 911 begging for help. In the painful years since that day, Uvalde Mayor Don McLaughlin has sought answers for closure and for accountability. He told CNN's Shimon Prokupecz that he's met nothing but obstacles. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) MAYOR DON MCLAUGHLIN (R-UVALDE, TX): Most of the information we get, I'm sad to say, I'm glad it's coming out from people like yourself or another agency. We got more from that than we did anything. SHIMON PROKUPECZ, CNN SENIOR CRIME & JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT: Journalists.

utterances.speaker: MCLAUGHLIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's ridiculous, isn't it? It's pretty sad. Pretty sad.Part of me wants to say are we going to uncover something you don't want us to see? Are we going to uncover some radio transmissions that you didn't want us to hear? Is our investigator going to uncover that? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: As far as we know, he is the only one in the room. But now supposedly kids in there, too.

utterances.speaker: MCLAUGHLIN
utterances.sentences: If we can find mistakes that we made, perhaps we can keep it from happening in some other community.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It is cold.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Do you think that you will ever see what you want done, what you think needs to be done to protect your kids who are still living in the community?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I think that we'll make sure of it.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: That was a clip from this week's episode of "THE WHOLE STORY" with Anderson Cooper.And with us now is CNN senior crime and justice correspondent, Shimon Prokupecz. He and his team won a Peabody Award for their extensive coverage of the story. And, Shimon, you also spoke with two 10-year-old survivors who lost their friends that day.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. Jayden and A.J. lost friends. A.J. was shot in the leg. Jayden was not hurt. But certainly is going through a really rough time in life. And the psychological and emotional scars very visible when you talk to him.They were both inside the classroom. Both hiding, both faking their death so that they could survive. Take a listen to what they told me about their lives today. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Do you ever think about your friends from class that day?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED BOY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: What do you think about?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED BOY
utterances.sentences: I think that I miss them.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: How about you, Jayden?

utterances.speaker: JAYDEN GONZALES, SURVIVOR OF ROBB ELEMENTARY SCHOOL SHOOTING
utterances.sentences: I miss my friends.

utterances.speaker: AZENETH RODRIGUEZ, MOTHER OF JAYDEN GONZALES
utterances.sentences: I mean, there is a lot of differences in between him since that day. Like certain things trigger him.This lady looked at him with the evil eyes and he had an anxiety attack and he was like, Mom, it reminded me back to the way the gunman was looking at me with his evil eyes. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What happened?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED BOY
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: You're on the headphones a lot.J. GONZALES: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Why?J. GONZALES: So it will help me so -- so if I hear something bad, I can just put my headphones on so I won't have to hear it. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Yes. And, Shimon, this is such important work that you have done here.I just have to say, I've watched you over the course of the year as you have become invested in finding answers for these families. And I've seen the pain in how you are just trying to cover it. And not to make you the story, I think the point is that you aren't the story. And yet even just the pain of covering it, which is eclipsed by the pain that the families feel. But just the proximity to trying to claw the answers out of the situation. And the enormity of what the families are feeling. You can't even imagine it. But you have this view to it having been with them so far of the way.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: And they know that I have seen things.I got a call today from a parent who said I want to see some video too because they know that I have seen everything and they want to see everything because they are trying to just get some information about exactly what happened to their kids. It is a role I've been forced to play that I never thought that I would have to play. Certainly, not as a journalist. It has been difficult but important work. And, no, I'm not the story but, of course, it has been very painful because I have had to be there during some of the most painful moments for these family members. And for my team, the year has been very difficult. But nothing compares to what these families have had to deal with. In part, the pain is because they don't get the answers. They don't have the accountability. We have a year later, and quite honestly, nothing in this community has changed. Nothing, Brianna, has changed.
